author: GimmeAllDaTendiesNow
body:
>It is a directional play and has 2X the downside risk to the strike the calls were purchased, for only 1X upside potential.

I'm not sure what you mean by this. With any long option or spread, your max loss is the price you paid. The upside potential is unlimited. It's 100 long deltas.

I suppose in this case you could divide the premium by 100 and say that's your range before max loss. A spread with 100 deltas will roughly behave that way, but not exactly, since you'll lose net deltas if the underlying moves against you.

>Not a bad idea if you're confident in direction. Could bite you if direction doesn't work out and you have no hedge.

OP is asking about a PMCC. This is a simulated stock position which is directional. I'm suggesting other ways to simulate stock than just a far dated, deep ITM call.

>I believe Liz and Jenny from TastyTrade/Works created this idea - or at least brought it to the public eye.

That's correct that TT coined that phrase and popularized the idea. Backspreads or back ratio-spreads have been around long before TT. Any long ratio spread will reduce your negative extrinsic value. The ZEBRA is a specific type of backspread that seeks to have zero extrinsic. I just find it's easier to explain it rather than confuse people with specific names.

>The idea that extrinsic values are negative is in how you frame the value of an option.

Not really. This is just options terminology. If something works in your favor you are "long" or it's "positive." Same as any greek or price factor. If you buy an option, you have "negative" extrinsic, meaning that value will work against you over time. If you sell an option, you have positive extrinsic. It's not something TT invented.

>Option Premium = intrinsic + extrinsic

This is true for ITM options. OTM options do not have intrinsic value and will decay to zero, as long as they stay OTM. The same way deep ITM options have very little extrinsic.

author: ConcentrateKooky933
body:
The position is called a ZEBRA spread. 

Zero Extrinsic Back Ratio.

I believe Liz and Jenny from TastyTrade/Works created this idea - or at least brought it to the public eye. 

2 long call DITM options and 1 short less ITM(closer to ATM) call to offset the extrinsic cost of the 2 longs. It replicates buying stock for a much cheaper price which is basically like "renting the stock" as you mentioned. 

It is a directional play and has 2X the downside risk to the strike the calls were purchased, for only 1X upside potential.

Not a bad idea if you're confident in direction. Could bite you if direction doesn't work out and you have no hedge. 



The idea that extrinsic values are negative is in how you frame the value of an option.

Option Premium = intrinsic + extrinsic 

If you treat extrinsic negative, you must treat intrinsic negative and vice versa.

This is a function of how you would treat long or short position and whether the premium is working for or against you. 


In calculation though. Intrinsic and Extrinsic are typically positive. Sign changes are made to a trader's liking/understanding. 

I know TastyWorks does this negative stuff but IMO it is not a good idea. It confuses people more than it helps if you ask me.

An option must have an extrinsic value until full expiration. When you introduce terms like negative extrinsic it becomes very nuanced and could confuse someone into thinking that extrinsic value doesn't exist, it actually reduces the cost of the option! Or something like that... this is not true and is why I dislike the the usage/perspective of explaining it as a negative value without full and proper context. 

Just my 2 cents.

author: New-Manufacturer-465
body:
I own a little stock, some 21jan22 ITM calls and mostly front month Zebras (from tastytrade). I don't want to limit my upside (in case of MOASS) so that rules out selling put credit spreads, cash secured puts or covered calls. I don't want big theta decay so that rules out OTM calls.

Zebras work better for AMC since there is little theta decay, little change with IV and 100 delta. Zebra is a back ratio that acts like the stock but has about 3 to 1 leverage. An example position:

sell one 15oct21 45c. buy two 15oct 36c at a cost of $1500. This is the near equivalent of 100 shares that cost  $4500. Delta is 103.  Theta decay is near zero.  IV change has little effect. Max gain is infinite. Max loss is $1500. I can hold this to the last week before expiration and then roll to the next month.

author: NobodyImportant13
body:
>but would it take even less BP doing a tighter PCS

Yes, with a tight spread it would take less BP but also you would be burning much more theta and have lower delta.  With a true synthetic you don't have to pay a debit.  If you go tight spread you would have less downside but pay a larger debit for the call.

>Also can you detail the last ‘bonus’ he provided long 2x 75D and short the 50D - wouldn’t this just be a call debit spread plus another long call?

Yes, you can think of it that way.  Specifically, it's a back ratio spread.

>Wouldn’t it theoretically be better to do calendars/PMCCs?

The ZEBRA strategy stands for "Zero Extrinsic Back Ratio"  It is actually similar to just buying LEAPS, but your breakeven will be at the current stock price since you are cancelling out the extrinsic value.  With LEAPS your breakeven will be something greater than the current stock price.

author: JosefTor7
body:
Why not just buy a synthetic long option by buying a call atm and selling a put atm? You can usually do this for a net credit, IV crush is not an issue, high volatility isn't an issue, if performed on an index, early assignment isn't a risk, etc. The only issue I see is that risk is not as well defined as a LEAPS so you could technically go all the way to zero from the stock price so you'd have to be careful to not buy too many. This will give you pretty descent leverage (4x).

The zebra strategy is a good one look at two but harder to manage then a synthetic long stock. Anyone have thoughts if this would be better than trading the LEAPS which everyone has mentioned will be impacted by the high IV environment after the crash.
